name: Ukraine
currentCrisisSummary:
Since Russia's 2022 invasion, Ukraine suffers a **devastating conflict**, inflicting **immense human suffering**. Millions are displaced, cities destroyed, and tens of thousands killed.

The war is an act of **brutal Russian imperialism**, but inseparable from **decades of eastward NATO expansion**. It is a catastrophic outcome of **inter-imperialist rivalry**, turning Ukraine into a proxy battleground. Massive Western arms flows sustain the war but also **deepen Ukraine's dependency** and integrate it into a Western-dominated structure, with Ukrainians paying the price. This **disaster capitalism** framework shapes the ongoing conflict and planned reconstruction.

imperialRoot.legacy:
Ukraine's history is deeply marked by its position between competing empires. For centuries, it was subjected to the Russian Empire, which suppressed Ukrainian language and identity in a project of colonial Russification. In the Soviet period, this continued through centralised control from Moscow, political purges, and the engineered famine of the Holodomor, which killed millions. This long history of domination informs both modern Ukrainian national identity and Russia's neo-imperial claims over the country.

Following the collapse of the USSR in 1991, the United States and its NATO allies engaged in a triumphalist eastward expansion. This process treated Eastern Europe as a strategic frontier to be absorbed, breaking informal assurances given to Soviet leaders and progressively encircling Russia. This expansion of a rival military and economic bloc created the structural conditions for today's conflict by ignoring security red lines and fostering instability.

historicalContext.title: NATO Eastward Expansion
historicalContext.description: The post-Cold War expansion of NATO into the former Warsaw Pact countries and Baltic states was a primary driver of the escalating geopolitical crisis. Framed in the West as a defensive measure for new democracies, it was perceived by Russia as an aggressive encroachment on its sphere of influence and a direct security threat. This relentless military expansion, against the warnings of many strategists, created a zero-sum security dilemma that ultimately shattered the European peace and contributed directly to the decision by Russia to invade.

historicalContext.title: Post-Soviet Neoliberalism and Oligarchy
historicalContext.description: The 'shock therapy' economic policies promoted by Western institutions like the IMF in the 1990s were imposed on both Russia and Ukraine. This rapid, mass privatisation of state assets allowed a small class of politically connected individualsâ€”the oligarchsâ€”to accumulate vast wealth and power. This process hollowed out the state, created deep-seated corruption, and made both countries' economies dependent on raw material exports and vulnerable to external pressures. The current conflict is, in part, a violent struggle between these rival oligarchic capitalist states.

historicalContext.title: The Post-2014 Neoliberal Turn
historicalContext.description: Following the 2014 Maidan Uprising, successive pro-Western governments, heavily guided by the IMF and Western powers, implemented a second wave of deep neoliberal reforms. These included severe austerity measures, the privatisation of state assets, and, most controversially, the opening of Ukraine's vast, fertile agricultural land to the market. While promoted as modernisation, these policies were often conditions for Western financial aid and deepened the country's economic dependency, creating social hardship that complicated the post-2014 political landscape.

historicalContext.title: War and Disaster Capitalism
historicalContext.description: The 2022 invasion has created the conditions for 'disaster capitalism'. Ukraine's Western partners are planning a post-war reconstruction that is explicitly designed along neoliberal lines, funded by loans that will lock the country into decades of debt to international financial institutions. This process prioritises privatisation and opportunities for foreign corporations to acquire key Ukrainian assets. The war, therefore, serves not only as a geopolitical battleground but also as a brutal mechanism for permanently restructuring Ukraine's economy in the interests of Western capital.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Russia's invasion is a clear violation of the UN Charter and international law. There is extensive documentation of war crimes, including indiscriminate attacks on civilian areas, summary executions, and torture. The ICC has issued arrest warrants for Russian officials. Simultaneously, critics point to the selective application of international law by Western powers, who have themselves engaged in illegal invasions and interventions (e.g., Iraq, Libya) without facing accountability, thereby weakening the international legal order that they now invoke.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands of civilians killed (likely far higher than official counts), victims of **Russia's aggression and the brutality of modern industrial warfare.** Military deaths number in the hundreds of thousands.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 14.6 million people require aid due to the **devastation inflicted by the invasion and the subsequent proxy war.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Approximately 3.7 million internally displaced, forced from homes by **Russian military advances, occupation, and indiscriminate attacks.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugee Crisis
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 6.5 million refugees globally, driven abroad by the **violence and destruction stemming from the inter-imperialist conflict.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Under Attack
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 1,500 verified attacks on healthcare, crippling access to medical care as **infrastructure is deliberately targeted or destroyed in the fighting.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Economic Devastation
humanitarianImpact.description: Ukraine's economy shrunk by a third, plunging millions into poverty as the **war destroys infrastructure and disrupts production, exacerbated by neoliberal vulnerabilities.**

timeline.event: **The Holodomor ('Death by Hunger')**: A man-made famine engineered by the Soviet state under Joseph Stalin kills millions of Ukrainians. The event is a foundational national trauma that informs Ukraine's deep-seated desire for sovereignty and its suspicion of Moscow's intentions.
**Independence**: Ukraine declares independence from the Soviet Union, marking a new era of sovereignty but also of geopolitical vulnerability between Russia and the West.

**Budapest Memorandum**: Ukraine agrees to give up its inherited Soviet nuclear arsenal in exchange for security assurances from Russia, the US, and the UK, guaranteeing its territorial integrityâ€”assurances later violated by Russia's invasions.
**First Wave of NATO Expansion**: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic join NATO, beginning the alliance's formal eastward push that Russia perceives as a threat.

**Orange Revolution**: Mass protests overturn a fraudulent presidential election, installing a pro-Western government. The event highlights the escalating tug-of-war over Ukraine's geopolitical alignment.

**Bucharest NATO Summit**: At its summit in Bucharest, NATO formally declares that Ukraine and Georgia 'will become members of NATO'. The declaration crosses a major Russian red line and is cited by many critical analysts as the point where a future conflict became highly probable.

**Maidan Uprising & Annexation of Crimea**: A popular uprising, which includes significant far-right elements, overthrows the elected pro-Russian government. Russia responds by illegally annexing Crimea and instigating a separatist war in the Donbas region.

**Post-Maidan Neoliberalism**: Following the uprising, Ukraine's pro-Western governments, backed by the IMF, enact harsh austerity and privatisation reforms, including opening the country's vast agricultural land market.

**Full-Scale Russian Invasion**: Citing NATO expansion and the protection of Russian speakers, Russia launches a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, triggering the largest conventional war in Europe since WWII.
**War of Attrition & Proxy Conflict**: The war settles into a brutal conflict heavily supplied by NATO, confirming its status as a proxy war between Russia and the West fought on Ukrainian soil.

advocacy: Oppose all imperialist aggression, including Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the decades-long military expansion of NATO that created the conditions for war.
Call for an immediate ceasefire and a negotiated diplomatic settlement to end the bloodshed, rather than military escalation.
Advocate for the cancellation of Ukraine's foreign debt to ensure that post-war reconstruction benefits its people, not international financial institutions and corporations.
Support peace movements and conscientious objectors in Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus who oppose the war.
Demand self-determination for the Ukrainian people, free from domination by any foreign power, whether from the East or the West.

reading.title: Frontline Ukraine: Crisis in the Borderlands
reading.description: Richard Sakwa provides a critical analysis of the crisis's roots, focusing on Ukraine's internal divisions and the dual pressures from Russia and NATO.

reading.title: The Tragedy of Great Power Politics
reading.description: John Mearsheimer's foundational text on 'offensive realism,' framing the war as a predictable outcome of great power competition and NATO expansion.

reading.title: Not One Inch: America, Russia, and the Making of Post-Cold War Stalemate
reading.description: M.E. Sarotte's historical account reveals how US-led NATO expansion broke post-Cold War promises, setting the stage for conflict.
